sen.j: 地頭（じとう）は、鎌倉幕府・室町幕府が荘園・国衙領（公領）を管理支配するために設置した職。
sen.e: Jito is a post established by Kamakura bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun) and Muromachi bakufu to manage and control shoen (manor) and kokuga-ryo (koryo, or an Imperial demesne).
Jito was a post established by Kamakura bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun) and Muromachi bakufu to manage and control shoen (manor) and kokuga-ryo (koryo, or an Imperial demesne).

Jito was a post established by Kamakura bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun) and Muromachi bakufu to manage and control shoen (manor) and kokuga-ryo (koryo (duchy), or an Imperial demesne).

sen.j: 地頭職という。
sen.e: It is called jitoshiki.
It is called jitoshiki.
It is called jitoshiki.

sen.j: 守護とともに設置された。
sen.e: It was established along with shugo (provincial constable).
It was established along with shugo (provincial constable).
It was established along with shugo (provincial constable).

sen.j: 平氏政権期以前から存在したが、源頼朝が朝廷から認められ正式に全国に設置した。
sen.e: It did existed before the period of Taira clan government, but it was established formally throughout the country by MINAMOTO no Yoritomo after approved by Imperial Court.
It existed before the period of the Taira clan government, but it was established formally throughout the country by MINAMOTO no Yoritomo after approval by the Imperial Court.
It existed before the period of the Taira clan government, but it was established formally throughout the country by MINAMOTO no Yoritomo after approval by the Imperial Court.
sen.cmt: 余分なスペースを削除しました。

sen.j: 在地御家人の中から選ばれ、荘園・公領の軍事・警察・徴税・行政をみて、直接、土地や百姓などを管理した。
sen.e: It was selected from local gokenin (an immediate vassal of the shogunate in the Kamakura and Muromachi through Edo periods), and managed land, peasants, and so on directly by looking after military affairs, police powers, tax collection, and administration of shoen and koryo.

It was selected from local gokenin (immediate vassal of the shogunate in the Kamakura and Muromachi through Edo periods), and managed land, peasants, and so on directly by looking after military affairs, police powers, tax collection, and administration of shoen and koryo.

Jitos (land stewards) were chosen from among immediate vassals of the shogunate who lived in local territories in order to manage land and peasants directly by supervising the military affairs, police forces, tax collection and administration of manors and imperial territories.
sen.cmt: FBに基づき修正しました。

sen.j: また、江戸時代にも領主のことを地頭と呼んだ。
sen.e: Also, feudal lord in Edo Period was called jito, too.
Also, feudal lords in the Edo Period were also called jito.
During the Edo period, feudal lords were also called jito.
sen.cmt: FBに基づき修正しました。

sen.j: （頼朝花押）
sen.e: (Signature by Yoritomo)
(Signature by Yoritomo)
(Signature by Yoritomo)

sen.j: 下 伊勢国波出御厨 補任 地頭職事 左兵衛尉惟宗忠久
sen.e: Order. To Isenokuni Hade no Mikuriya (伊勢国波出御厨) (Hade no Mikuriya in Ise Province). Matter of assigning jitoshiki. To Sahyoe no jo (third-ranked officer of Sahyoe-fu, the Left Division of Middle Palace Guards) Tadahisa KOREMUNE.
sen.cmt: 伊勢国波出御厨→表記不明です→Hase no mikuriya (manors of Imperial family and powerful shrines) in Ise Province[http://www.hi.u-tokyo.ac.jp/publication/syoho/43/pub_eiin-shimadu-rekidaikikanhokan.html]古文の為意訳です
sen.e: Order. To Isenokuni Hade no Mikuriya (伊勢国波出御厨) (Hade no Mikuriya in Ise Province). Matter of assigning jitoshiki. To Sahyoe no jo (third-ranked officer of Sahyoe-fu, the Left Division of Middle Palace Guards) Tadahisa KOREMUNE.
I hereby appoint Tadahisa KOREMUNE, third-ranked officer of the Left Division of Middle Palace Guards, as the jito of a manor in Ise Province.
sen.cmt: FBに基づき修正しました。provinceの頭文字を大文字に変更

sen.j: 右、件所者、故出羽守平信兼党類領也。
sen.e: In the right was a territory belonging to group of former Dewa no kami (the governor of Dewa Province), TAIRA no Nobukane.
At the right was a territory belonging to a group of former Dewa no kami (Governor of Dewa Province), TAIRA no Nobukane.
The territory has been ruled by the group led by TAIRA no Nobukane, former governor of Dewa Province.
sen.cmt: FBに基づき修正しました。provinceの頭文字を大文字に変更、カンマ→ピリオドに修正

sen.j: 而信兼依発謀反、令追討畢。
sen.e: Since Nobukane made rebellion, order is made to hunt down and kill him.
Since Nobukane made rebellion, an order was made to hunt him down and kill him.
However, since Nobukane rose up in rebellion, an order was issued to hunt down and kill him.
sen.cmt: FBに基づき修正しました。

sen.j: 仍任先例為令勤仕公役、所補地頭職也。
sen.e: Following the precedent, in order to make you a public official, you are assigned to jitoshiki.
Following this precedent, in order to make you a public official, you are assigned to jitoshiki.
Therefore, in accordance with precedents, I hereby assign Tadahisa KOREMUNE as the new jito of the territory.
sen.cmt: FBに基づき修正しました。

sen.j: 早為彼職可致沙汰之状如件。
sen.e: Perform your duty as jito promptly.
Perform your duty as jito promptly.
Let him promptly perform his duty.
sen.cmt: FBに基づき修正しました。

sen.j: 以下。
sen.e: That is an order.
That is an order.
That is an order.

sen.j: 元暦二年六月十五日
以上は、惟宗忠久を波出御厨（伊勢国）地頭職に補任する内容の源頼朝による下文。
sen.e: Above is an official document by MINAMOTO no Yoritomo with content assigning Tadahisa KOREMUNE as jitoshiki of Hade no Mikuriya (Ise Province).
Above is an official document by MINAMOTO no Yoritomo with contents assigning Tadahisa KOREMUNE as jitoshiki of Hade no Mikuriya (Ise Province).
The above is an official document written by MINAMOTO no Yoritomo in order to appoint Tadahisa KOREMUNE as the land steward of the Hase imperial territory in Ise Province.
sen.cmt: FBに基づき修正しました。provinceの頭文字を大文字に変更

sen.j: 幕府が御家人の所領支配を保証することを本領安堵（ほんりょうあんど）といい、幕府が新たに所領を与えることを新恩給与（しんおんきゅうよ）という。
sen.e: Guarantee made for gokenin to rule their territories by bakufu is called honryo-ando, and it is called shinon-kyuyo when bakufu gives new territory, and they were both done through the means of assigning as jitoshiki.

A guarantee made for gokenin to rule their territories by bakufu was called honryo-ando, and it is called shinon-kyuyo when bakufu gave new territory, and they were both done through the means of assignment as jitoshiki.

The guarantee given by the bakufu to protect a hereditary territory ruled by its vassal was known as "honryo-ando" (assurance of territorial rights), while the allocation of a new territory by the government was called "shinon-kyuyo" (territory allocation).
sen.cmt: FBに基づき修正しました。一原文一訳文の例外対処shogunate government→bakufuに修正

sen.j: いずれも地頭職への補任という手段を通じて行われた。
sen.e: Both these procedures were put into effect by appointing vassals as land stewards.
sen.cmt: FBに基づき修正しました。一原文一訳文の例外対処

sen.j: 地頭職への補任は、所領そのものの支給ではなく、所領の管理・支配の権限を認めることを意味していた。
sen.e: When assigned to jitoshiki, it didn't mean that the territory itself was provided, but it meant that the authority to control and rule the territory was approved.
When assigned to jitoshiki, it did not mean that the territory itself was provided, but it meant that the authority to control and rule the territory was approved.
A vassal appointed as a land steward of a territory was not provided with the territory itself, but only the authority to control and rule the territory.
sen.cmt: FBに基づき修正しました。

sen.j: 所領を巡る紛争（所務沙汰）の際には、幕府の保証する地頭の地位だけでは必ずしも十分ではない場合もあり、地頭の中には荘園領主・国司から荘官、郡司、郷司、保司として任命される者も少なくなかった。
sen.e: Since the post of jito, guaranteed by bakufu, was not always enough by itself in a dispute over territory (shomusata), so many of jito were also assigned as shokan (an officer governing shoen), gunji (local magistrates), goji (a local government official under the ritsuryo system, a system of centralized government based on the ritsuryo code), and hoshi (an officer governing koryo) by lords of shoen and kokushi (provincial governors).

Since the post of jito, guaranteed by bakufu, was not always enough by itself in a dispute over territory (shomusata), many jito were also assigned as shokan (an officer governing shoen), gunji (local magistrates), goji (a local government official under the ritsuryo system, a system of centralized government based on the ritsuryo code), and hoshi (an officer governing koryo) by lords of shoen and kokushi (provincial governors).

Since vassals appointed as land stewards by the bakufu did not always have the authority to settle territorial disputes, they were also often appointed by manorial lords and imperial government officials as manorial officials ("shokan" in Japanese), local magistrates ("gunji"), local administrators ("goji") or governor of imperial territories ("hoji") to give them appropriate authority.
sen.cmt: FBに基づき修正しました。shogunate government→bakufuに修正

sen.j: つまり地頭は、幕府及び荘園領主・国司からの二重支配を受けていたと見ることもできる訳である。
sen.e: In other words, it is possible to see that jito was double-ruled by both bakufu, and lords of shoen and kokushi.
In other words, it is possible to see that jito was double-ruled by both bakufu, and lords of shoen and kokushi.
In a certain sense, therefore, land stewards were ruled not only by the bakufu but also by manorial lords and imperial government officials.
sen.cmt: FBに基づき修正しました。shogunate government→bakufuに修正

sen.j: 実際に、幕府が定めた法典御成敗式目には、荘園領主への年貢未納があった場合には地頭職を解任するといった条文もあった。
sen.e: Actually, there was an provision stating that when nengu (land tax) was unpaid, he will be removed from jitoshiki post in Goseibai-shikimoku (code of conduct for samurai) made by the bakufu.
Actually, there was a provision stating that when nengu (land tax) was unpaid, he will be removed from the jitoshiki post by Goseibai-shikimoku (code of conduct for samurai) made by the bakufu.
In fact, there was a provision in the code for samurai established by the bakufu (known as "Goseibai Shikimoku") that land stewards who failed to collect taxes for manorial lords should be dismissed.
sen.cmt: FBに基づき修正しました。shogunate government→bakufuに修正

sen.j: むしろ、幕府に直属する武士は御家人と地頭の両方の側面を持ち、御家人としての立場は鎌倉殿への奉仕であり、地頭職は、徴税、警察、裁判の責任者として国衙と荘園領主に奉仕する立場であったとする解釈もある。
sen.e: Rather, there is an interpretation recognizing that samurai, who were under direct control of the bakufu, had sides as both gokenin and jito, with gokenin's position of serving Kamakura-dono (lord of Kamakura), and jitoshiki's position of serving kokushi and lords of shoen as ones in charge of collecting taxes, police powers, and holding trials.

Rather, there was an interpretation recognizing that samurai, who were under the direct control of the bakufu, had sides as both gokenin and jito, with the gokenin position serving Kamakura-dono (lord of Kamakura), and the jitoshiki position serving kokushi and the lords of shoen as the ones in charge of collecting taxes, police powers, and holding trials.

It is even possible to see samurai who were under the direct control of the bakufu as being hereditary retainers who served the Kamakura family and, at the same time, territorial governors who served imperial government officials and manorial lords by performing their duties to collect taxes, supervise police activities and preside over trials.
sen.cmt: FBに基づき修正しました。shogunate government→bakufuに修正the Kamakura family→こちらの用語ご確認お願い致します。(鎌倉殿=鎌倉幕府の将軍の意、参照: http://dictionary.goo.ne.jp/leaf/jn/37651/m0u/%E3%81%8B%E3%81%BE/)

sen.j: しかし、地頭の補任権・解任権は幕府だけが有しており、荘園領主・国司にはその権限がなかった。
sen.e: But only the bakufu had the power to assign and discharge jito, and lords of shoen and kokushi didn't.
But only the bakufu had the power to assign and discharge jito, and the lords of shoen and kokushi did not.
However, the bakufu alone had the right to appoint and discharge land stewards and neither manorial lords nor imperial government officials had any such right.
sen.cmt: FBに基づき修正しました。shogunate government→bakufuに修正

sen.j: そのため、地頭はその地位を背景に、勧農の実施などをとおして荘園・公領の管理支配権を徐々に奪っていった。
sen.e: As a result, with that position in their back, jito gradually deprived lords of shoen and kokushi of the power of controlling and ruling shoen and koryo through the means of encouraging agriculture and so on.
As a result, with this position, jito gradually deprived the lords of shoen and kokushi of the power of controlling and ruling shoen and koryo through the means of encouraging agriculture and so on.
Consequently, land stewards used their position to gradually seize the power to control and rule manors and imperial territories by various means, including promoting farming.
sen.cmt: FBに基づき修正しました。

sen.j: 具体的には、地頭は様々な理由をつけては荘園領主・国司への年貢を滞納・横領し、両者間に紛争が生じると、毎年一定額の年貢納入や荘園の管理を請け負う地頭請（じとううけ）を行うようになった。
sen.e: For example, giving various reasons, jito unpaid or embezzled nengu to the lords of shoen and kokushi, and when disputes arose between them, they started to conduct jitouke, or undertaking of the fixed amount payment of nengu and the control of shoen.

For example, giving various reasons, jito did not pay, or embezzled, nengu to the lords of shoen and kokushi, and when disputes arose between them, they started to conduct jitouke, or undertaking a fixed payment of nengu and the control of shoen.

For example, they refused to pay taxes to manorial lords and imperial officials or even misappropriated taxes on various pretexts, and when disputes arose between manorial lords and imperial officials, they contracted to provide them with fixed amounts of annual taxes and to manage manors.
sen.cmt: FBに基づき修正しました。

sen.j: 地頭請は、不作の年でも約束額を領主・国司へ納入するといったリスクを負ってはいたが、一定額の年貢の他は自由収入とすることができたため、地頭にとって多大な利益をもたらすことが多かった。
sen.e: Jitouke did have the risk of paying agreed amount to lords and kokushi even in a year of crop failure, but most of the time it made great deal of profit for jito since the rest of nengu,after paying fixed amount to the lords and kokushi, could be made as their free income.

Jitouke did have the risk of paying an agreed amount to lords and kokushi even in a year of crop failure, but most of the time it made a great deal of profit for jito since the remainder of the nengu, after paying the fixed amount to the lords and kokushi, could be used as their free income.

The subcontract system entailed the risk of having to make payments fixed by contracts to manorial lords and imperial officials even in poor crop years, but the amounts of crops exceeding fixed payments were treated as land stewards' private income, which often brought them considerable benefits.
sen.cmt: FBに基づき修正しました。

sen.j: そして、この制度により地頭は荘園・公領の事実上の支配権を握った。
sen.e: And then, with this system, jito became to hold the actual power of ruling shoen and koryo.
And then, with this system, jito came to hold the actual power of ruling shoen and koryo.
Taking advantage of this system, land stewards came to establish effective control of manors and imperial territories.
sen.cmt: FBに基づき修正しました。

sen.j: それでも荘園領主・国司へ約束額を納入しない地頭がいたため、荘園・公領の領域自体を地頭と領主・国司で折半する中分（ちゅうぶん）が行われることもあった。
sen.e: However, there were still jito who didn't pay agreed amount of taxes to the lords of shoen and kokushi, so sometimes a chubun, or a division of territory of shoen and koryo itself, took place.

However, there were still jito who did not pay the agreed amount of taxes to the lords of shoen and kokushi, so sometimes a chubun, or a division of the territory of shoen and koryo itself, took place.

Since land stewards often failed to pay agreed amounts of taxes to manorial lords or imperial officials even under this subcontract system, some manors and imperial territories were divided between land stewards and manorial lords or imperial officials.
sen.cmt: FBに基づき修正しました。

sen.j: 中分には、両者の談合（和与）で決着する和与中分（わよちゅうぶん）や、荘園・公領に境界を引いて完全に分割する下地中分（したじちゅうぶん）があった。
sen.e: There were wayo chubun, when a chubun was settled in a conference, and shitaji chubun, when shoen and koryo were divided completely by a border.
There were wayo chubun, when a chubun was settled in a conference, and shitaji chubun, when shoen and koryo were divided completely by a border.
Sometimes territories were divided based on mutual agreement (called "wayo chubun") and sometimes lines were drawn in manors and imperial territories to show boundaries (called "shitaji chubun").
sen.cmt: FBに基づき修正しました。

sen.j: 地頭は、居館（堀内：ほりうち等と称した）の周辺に直営地を保有していた。
sen.e: Jito possessed their directly managed land around their residence (called horiuchi and so on).
Jito possessed their directly managed land around their residence (called horiuchi and so on).
Land steward possessed land under their direct management (called "horiuchi," etc.) around their residences.
sen.cmt: FBに基づき修正しました。

sen.j: 平安～鎌倉期の慣習では、居館は年貢・公事が免除される土地とされており、それを根拠として、地頭は居館の周辺を免税地として直営するようになった。
sen.e: In a custom in Heian-Kamakura period, their residence were assumed as land free from nengu and kuji (public duties), and using that as a ground, jito managed directly the land around their residence as tax-free land.

In a custom of the Heian-Kamakura period, their residences were assumed as land free from nengu and kuji (public duties), and using this as grounds, jito managed directly the land around their residence as tax-free land.

Since it was customary for residences to be exempted from taxation during the Heian and Kamakura periods, land stewards took advantage of this custom to place land around their residences under their direct management.
sen.cmt: FBに基づき修正しました。

sen.j: この直営地は、佃（つくだ）、御作（みつくり）、正作（しょうさく）、門田（かどた）などと呼ばれ、地頭の従属民である下人（げにん）や所従（しょじゅう）、又は荘民に耕作をさせていた。
sen.e: These directly managed land were called tukuda, mitukuri, shosaku, kadota, and so on, and jito made their subordinated peasants, called genin and shoju, and peasants in shoen to cultivate them.
These directly managed lands were called tukuda, mitukuri, shosaku, kadota, and so on, and jito made their subordinated peasants, called genin and shoju, and peasants in shoen, cultivate them.

These pieces of land under their direct management were called by different names, such as "tsukuda" (private land), "mitsukuri" (privately cultivated land), "shosaku" (privately owned land) or "kadota" (family land), and were cultivated by their servants called "genin" or "shoju" or by village farmers.
sen.cmt: FBに基づき修正しました。

sen.j: この直営地からの収入は、そのまま地頭の収入となった。
sen.e: Incomes from there directly managed land all became the incomes of jito.
Income from there directly managed lands became the income of the jito.
Yields from these pieces of land were treated as land stewards' income.
sen.cmt: FBに基づき修正しました。

sen.j: 以上のような地頭請・下地中分・直営地の拡大は、地頭が荘園・国衙領の土地支配権（下地進止権）へ侵出していったことを表す。
sen.e: The spread of jitouke, shitaji chubun, and directly managed land like above show that jito started to aggress the right to rule shoen and kokuga-ryo (shitaji-shinshi ken).
The spread of jitouke, shitaji chubun, and directly managed land like the above show that jito started to aggressively rule shoen and kokuga-ryo (shitaji-shinshi ken).

The spread of subcontracting practices, boundary drawing and increase in directly managed land show the establishment of land stewards' right to control land (right to appropriate land) in manors and imperial territories.
sen.cmt: FBに基づき修正しました。

sen.j: 当然、荘園領主は地頭の動きに対抗していたが、全般的に見ると地頭の侵出は加速していった。
sen.e: Of course, the lords of shoen did oppose with these moves of jito, but looking as a whole, the advance of jito was accelerated.
Of course, the lords of shoen opposed these moves of the jito, but overall, the advancement of the jito was accelerated.
Despite the opposition by manorial lords against their encroachment, land stewards generally gained greater power as time went on.
sen.cmt: FBに基づき修正しました。

sen.j: こうした流れは、地頭による一円知行化へと進み、次第に荘園公領制の解体を推し進めたのである。
sen.e: Such current advanced to ichien-chigyo ka (monopolization of land by one authority) of land by jito, and gradually progressed the dissolution of the system of shoen and koryo.
Such a trend progressed to ichien-chigyo ka (monopolization of land by one authority) of land by jito, and gradually led to the dissolution of the system of shoen and koryo.
The encroachment by land stewards gradually resulted in their monopolization of land and led to the dissolution of the system of manors and imperial territories.
sen.cmt: FBに基づき修正しました。

sen.j: 地頭は元来、現地という意味を持ち、在地で荘園・公領の管理・治安維持に当たることを任務としていた。
sen.e: Jito, originally meaning the land, had the management and keeping of peace in shoen and koryo locally as their duties.
Jito, originally meaning land, had management and maintenance of the peace in shoen and koryo locally as their duties.
The word "jito" originally meant "field workers" who were in charge of the on-site management and security enforcement of manors and imperial territories.
sen.cmt: FBに基づき修正しました。ピリオド追加

sen.j: 多くの地頭は任務地に在住し、在地管理を行っていた。
sen.e: Most of jito lived in their place of duty, and managed locally.
Most jito lived in their place of duty, and managed locally.
Many land stewards lived in the territories to which they were assigned to manage local affairs on the ground.
sen.cmt: FBに基づき修正しました。

sen.j: しかし、有力御家人などは、幕府の役職を持ち、将軍へ伺候しなければならず、鎌倉に居住する者が多かった。
sen.e: However, most of powerful gokenin and so on, having a post in bakufu, had to serve shogun, and lived in Kamakura.
However, most powerful gokenin and so on, having posts in bakufu, had to serve the shogun, and lived in Kamakura.

However, powerful vassals of the Kamakura family who were appointed as land stewards also held important government posts, and since they had to serve the shogun in person, many of them continued to live in Kamakura.
sen.cmt: FBに基づき修正しました。the Kamakura family→こちらの用語ご確認下さい。

sen.j: そうした有力御家人は、自分の親族・家臣を現地へ派遣して在地管理を行わせていた。
sen.e: Such powerful gokenin dispatched their family and vassal to their land and made them do the local management.
Such powerful gokenin dispatched their family and vassals to their land and made them perform the local management.
These powerful vassals sent their relatives or retainers to local territories so as to have them manage local affairs on the ground.
sen.cmt: FBに基づき修正しました。

sen.j: 親族に管理させた場合、御家人（惣領）とその親族（庶子）との間で所領を巡る相論が発生することもあり、親族に地頭職を譲渡するケースもあった。
sen.e: When their families were managing, sometimes a suit was made between a gokenin (soryo) and his family (shoshi) about the territory, and there was a case when a gokenin handed over jitoshiki to his family.

When their families were managing, sometimes a suit was made between a gokenin (soryo) and his family (shoshi) about the territory, and there was a case where a gokenin handed over jitoshiki to his family.

Territories left in the hands of relatives often caused disputes between vassals (legitimate heirs) and these relatives (illegitimate children) over these territories, and in such cases, relatives were sometimes allowed to succeed as land stewards.
sen.cmt: FBに基づき修正しました。

sen.j: 地頭の在地管理のあり方を見ると、荘園領主と異なる点が見られる。
sen.e: When observing jito's local management, a different point can be seen from the management of lords of shoen.
When observing a jito's local management, a different point can be seen from the management of lords of shoen.
Land stewards differed from manorial lords in the way they managed local affairs.
sen.cmt: FBに基づき修正しました。

sen.j: 地頭は武士なので、紛争などを暴力的に解決しようとする傾向があった。
sen.e: Jito, since they were samurais, tend to settle disputes violently.
Jito, since they were samurai, tended to settle disputes violently.
Being warriors, land stewards often resorted to arms when settling disputes.
sen.cmt: FBに基づき修正しました。

sen.j: 著名な紀伊国阿弖河荘（あてがわのしょう）百姓訴状は、百姓が地頭の非法のせいで年貢（材木）納入が遅れたことを荘園領主に釈明した文書である。
sen.e: A famous petition by the peasants of Ategawa no sho in Kii Province is a document vindicating the delay of delivering nengu (in this case lumber) to the lord of shoen for the reason of jito's unlawfulness, and it is well-mentioned about how jito forcibly made impressments and how they threatened peasants by saying "I'll cut off your ear, chip off your nose, shave your hair, and make you a nun" when resisted.

A famous petition by the peasants of Ategawa no sho in Kii Province is a document vindicating the delay in delivering nengu (in this case lumber) to the lord of shoen for the reason of the jito's unlawfulness, and it mentioned often about how jito forcibly made impressions and how they threatened peasants by saying "I'll cut off your ear, chip off your nose, shave your hair, and make you a nun" when they resisted.

The well-known petition of peasants of the Ategawa manor in Kii Province is a document written by peasants to complain to their manorial lord about the delay in the payment of annual taxes (lumber) caused by wrongful actions by the land steward of their territory.
sen.cmt: FBに基づき修正しました。一原文一訳文の例外対処「紀伊国」を訳出

sen.j: 地頭が百姓を強引に徴発した様子、抵抗すると「耳を切り、鼻を削ぎ、髪を切って、尼にしてしまうぞ」と脅した様子などがよく記されている。
sen.e: The document describes how the land steward conscripted peasants for forced labor by threatening to "cut off the ears and noses" of resistant peasants and to "cut the hair of their wives to make them nuns."
sen.cmt: FBに基づき修正しました。一原文一訳文の例外対処

sen.j: また、「泣く子と地頭には勝てぬ」という言葉もある。
sen.e: There is a phrase saying 'it is no more possible to beat jito than to reason with a whining child.'
There was a phrase saying 'it is no more possible to beat jito than to reason with a whining child.'
There is also a Japanese saying that jito and whining children are the hardest people in the world to reason with.
sen.cmt: FBに基づき修正しました。

sen.j: 地頭は元々、平安時代中期頃から、土地のほとり、すなわち「現地」を意味する語として使用され始めたが、そのうち、現地で領地を支配する有力者、又は荘園を現地管理する荘官職、公領を現地管理する郡司、郷司、保司職を表すようになった。
sen.e: Originally, jito was used as a word meaning neighborhood of land or 'local', but by and by, it began to express its meaning as a powerful man who rules territory locally, or post of shokan who locally manage shoen, and post of gunji, goji, and hoshi who locally manage koryo.

Originally, jito was used as a word meaning neighborhood of land or 'local', but by and by, it began to express the meaning as a powerful man who ruled territory locally, or the post of shokan who locally managed shoen, and the posts of gunji, goji, and hoshi who locally managed koryo.

The word "jito," which began to be used around the mid-Heian period as a word meaning "boundaries" or "territories," came to mean influential people that ruled territories, officials that managed manors, or local government officials (variously called "gunji," "goji" or "hoshi") that managed imperial territories on the ground.
sen.cmt: FBに基づき修正しました。

sen.j: 平安末期の平氏政権下では、平氏が所領の現地管理者として家人の武士を地頭に任命した事例がわずかながらも見られたが、その実態や職務はよく判っていない。
sen.e: Under the Taira clan government in the last years of Heian period, a few cases of assigning retained samurai as the local manager of territory by Taira clan could be seen, but their actual conditions and duties are not yet well understood.

Under the Taira clan government in the last years of the Heian period, a few cases of assigning retained samurai as the local manager of the territory by the Taira clan were seen, but their actual conditions and duties are not well understood.

During the reign of the Taira clan in the late Heian period, there were a few cases where samurai retainers of the Taira clan were appointed as jito for the on-site management of territories, but the actual situations and duties of these jito are not known.
sen.cmt: FBに基づき修正しました。「平氏政権の末期」ではなく「平安末期」であるため、During the last years of the reign of the Taira clan→During the reign of the Taira clan in the late Heian period としました。

sen.j: 平氏政権に対抗して、関東に独自の支配権を確立した源頼朝の武士政権（後の鎌倉幕府）は、依ってきた武士（すなわち御家人）を地頭に任命することで、自らの支配権を強めていった。
sen.e: Samurai government by MINAMOTO no Yoritomo (later Kamakura bakufu) which established its original power of ruling in Kanto region, opposing to Taira clan government, strengthened its power by assigning its dependent samurai (or gokenin) as jito.

Samurai government by MINAMOTO no Yoritomo (later Kamakura bakufu), which established its original power of ruling in the Kanto region, opposing the Taira clan government, strengthened its power by assigning its dependent samurai (or gokenin) as jito.

The samurai government of MINAMOTO no Yoritomo (latter-day Kamakura bakufu), which established its rule in the Kanto region in opposition to the Taira clan, appointed its direct vassals (called "gokenin") as land stewards in order to strengthen its control.
sen.cmt: FBに基づき修正しました。Kamakura shogunate government→Kamakura bakufuに修正

sen.j: また、御家人の多くは、荘園の荘官、公領の郡司、郷司、保司であり、荘園領主（本所）や国司（特にその筆頭官としての受領）の家人・被官としての地位しか与えられていなかった。
sen.e: Also, most of gokenin were shokan of shoen and gunji, goji, and hoshi of koryo, and were only given their position as retainer and hikan (low-level bureaucrat) of lords of shoen (honjo, or proprietor or guarantor of manor) and kokushi (especially zuryo, or the head of the provincial governors), but their position as local feudal lord were accepted by having appointed as jitoshiki by Yoritomo government which actually ruled Kanto region.

Also, most gokenin were shokan of shoen and gunji, goji, and hoshi of koryo, and were only given their positions as retainers and hikan (low-level bureaucrats) of lords of shoen (honjo, or proprietor or guarantor of manor) and kokushi (especially zuryo, or the head of the provincial governors), but their position as local feudal lords were accepted by having been appointed as jitoshiki by the Yoritomo government which actually ruled the Kanto region.

Many of the vassals of the Kamakura family were officials of manors and imperial territories called "gunji," "goji" or "hoshi" who had been given status merely as servants or subordinates of manorial lords (called "honjo" (master) in Japanese) and imperial officials (more specifically, head official called "zuryo").
sen.cmt: FBに基づき修正しました。一原文一訳文の例外対処the Kamakura family→こちらの用語ご確認下さい。

sen.j: しかし、関東を実効支配していた頼朝政権に地頭職を補任されることにより、在地領主としての地位を認められたのである。
sen.e: However, by being appointed as land stewards by the government of Yoritomo which ruled the Kanto region, they were recognized as independent territorial rulers.
sen.cmt: FBに基づき修正しました。一原文一訳文の例外対処「関東を実効支配していた」を訳出

sen.j: ところで頼朝政権は当初、関東の私的な政治・軍事勢力に過ぎなかったが、平氏政権との内戦（治承・寿永の乱）を経るに従い、後白河天皇を中心とする公権力（朝廷）から徐々に東国支配権を認められていき、政権の正統性を獲得していった。
sen.e: By the way, Yoritomo government was only a private political and military power in Kanto region at first, but by experiencing through civil war (Jisho-Juei War) against the Taira clan government, its power to rule Togoku (the eastern part of Japan, particularly Kanto region) was gradually approved by the official authority (Imperial Court) with Emperor Goshirakawa as the leader, and obtained its legitimacy as the government.

By the way, Yoritomo government was only a private political and military power in the Kanto region at first, but by experiencing civil war (Jisho-Juei War) against the Taira clan government, its power to rule Togoku (the eastern part of Japan, particularly the Kanto region) was gradually approved by the official authority (Imperial Court) with Emperor Goshirakawa as the leader, and obtained its legitimacy as the government.

Although the Yoritomo government was initially a private political and military group in the Kanto region, it gradually gained recognition of the official authority (the imperial court), including Emperor Goshirakawa, as the ruler of eastern Japan and established its legitimacy as a government through its war with the Taira clan (Jisho-Juei War) in the late 12th century.
sen.cmt: FBに基づき修正しました。

sen.j: 1185年、頼朝政権が平家を滅ぼした直後、頼朝政権の一員だった源行家・源義経が頼朝へ反抗姿勢を見せ始めると、同年11月に頼朝義父の北条時政が上京し、後白河側と交渉を行い、その結果、頼朝側へ、行家・義経追討を名目として荘園・公領から兵糧米を徴収する職（＝地頭・守護）の設置が勅許されることとなった（文治の勅許）。
sen.e: In 1185, right after Yoritomo government destroyed the Taira clan, when MINAMOTO no Yoshiie and MINAMOTO no Yoshitsune, who were members of Yoritomo government, started to show attitude of resistance, Tokimasa HOJO, who was Yoritomo's father-in-law, went up to Kyoto and negotiated with Goshirakawa side, and as a result, under the pretext of hunting down and killing Yoshiie and Yoshitsune, Imperial sanction to establish a position to levy provisions of rice for the army from shoen and koryo (jito and shugo) was permitted (the Bunji imperial sanction) to Yoritomo side.

In 1185, right after the Yoritomo government destroyed the Taira clan, when MINAMOTO no Yoshiie and MINAMOTO no Yoshitsune, who were members of the Yoritomo government, started to show an attitude of resistance, Tokimasa HOJO, who was Yoritomo's father-in-law, went up to Kyoto and negotiated with the Goshirakawa side, and as a result, under the pretext of hunting down and killing Yoshiie and Yoshitsune, Imperial sanction to establish a position to levy provisions of rice for the army from shoen and koryo (jito and shugo) was permitted (the Bunji imperial sanction) to the Yoritomo side.

In 1185, when MINAMOTO no Yoshiie and MINAMOTO no Yoshitsune, who were members of the Yoritomo government, began to oppose Yoritomo immediately after his government defeated the Taira clan, Tokimasa HOJO, Yoritomo's father-in-law, visited Kyoto to negotiate with Emperor Goshirakawa's group in order to obtain imperial permission (the Bunji imperial permission) to create positions ("jito" (land steward) and "shugo" (provincial military governor)) and to collect supplies of rice for soldiers from manors and imperial territories for the purpose of hunting down and killing Yoshiie and Yoshitsune.
sen.cmt: FBに基づき修正しました。

sen.j: このことは、『吾妻鏡』（幕府の正史）及び『玉葉』（内覧・九条兼実の日記）に記録されている。
sen.e: This matter is recorded in "Azuma Kagami" (Mirror of Azuma, the chronicle of Azuma, official history of bakufu) and "Gyokuyo" (nairan, or a preliminary inspection of official documents submitted from the Great Council of State to the Emperor, diary of Kanezane KUJO), but the arguments of the sphere of duty and so forth of jito and shugo that were officially recognized at that time are split because the description of both articles are fragmentary and different.

This matter is recorded in "Azuma Kagami" (Mirror of Azuma, the chronicle of Azuma, official history of bakufu) and "Gyokuyo" (nairan, or a preliminary inspection of official documents submitted from the Great Council of State to the Emperor, diary of Kanezane KUJO), but the arguments regarding the sphere of duty and so forth by jito and shugo, which were officially recognized at that time, are split because the description of both articles are fragmentary and different.
These incidents are recorded in "Azuma Kagami" (official history of the Kamakura bakufu) and "Gyokuyo" (diary of Kanezane KUJO, an inspector of documents for the emperor).
sen.cmt: FBに基づき修正しました。一原文一訳文の例外対処Kamakura shogunate government→Kamakura bakufuに修正

sen.j: しかしながら、両者の記述は断片的かつ食い違う箇所があるため、このとき公認された地頭・守護の職務範囲等については議論が分かれている。
sen.e: However, due to the fragmentary nature of the descriptions and differences between the descriptions in the two documents, opinions differ as to the officially recognized definition of the duties of these newly created positions.
sen.cmt: FBに基づき修正しました。一原文一訳文の例外対処

sen.j: なお、鎌倉幕府の成立時期にはいくつかの説が提出されているが、そのうち、地頭・守護の設置は幕府の支配権が全国的な広がりを持つに至った非常に重要な画期であるとして、学界では最も多くの支持を集めている。
sen.e: Further, several theories are presented about the time of organization of Kamakura bakufu, but the theory stating that the establishment of jito and shugo is the beginning has the most support of learned society, for it was very important turning point of bakufu's ruling power to spread throughout the nation.

Further, several theories are presented about the time of organization of Kamakura bakufu, but the theory stating that the establishment of jito and shugo was the beginning has the most support in learned society, for it was a very important turning point for bakufu's ruling power to spread throughout the nation.

Of the several theories that have been proposed about when the Kamakura bakufu was established, the one that emphasizes the importance of the creation of the positions of jito (land steward) and shugo (provincial military governor) as an epoch-making development showing the nationwide establishment of the Kamakura bakufu rule is supported by the majority of scholars in Japan.
sen.cmt: FBに基づき修正しました。Kamakura shogunate government→Kamakura bakufu、Kamakura shogunate→Kamakura bakufuに修正

sen.j: 頼朝傘下の地頭・守護の公認に対しては、当然ながら荘園領主・国司（＝公家）からの反発があり、地頭の設置は平家没官領（平氏の旧所領）のみに限られるようになった（この限定の経緯についても諸説分かれている）。
sen.e: Of course, there were repellence against the authorization of jito and shugo under Yoritomo by the lords of shoen and kokushi (kuge, or a Court noble), and the positioning of jito became limited only to Heike Mokkanryo (former territory of the Taira clan) (the theories about the sequence of this limitation is split, too).

Of course, there was resistance against the authorization of jito and shugo under Yoritomo by the lords of shoen and kokushi (kuge, or a Court noble), and the positioning of jito became limited only to Heike Mokkanryo (former territory of the Taira clan) (theories about the sequence of this limitation are split, too).

Needless to say, manorial lords and imperial officials (court nobles) were opposed to the authorization of land stewards and military governors appointed by Yoritomo, and the appointment of land stewards was limited to imperial territories confiscated from the Taira clan (former territories of the Taira clan) (opinions also differ as to how the appointment of land stewards came to be limited to these territories).
sen.cmt: FBに基づき修正しました。

sen.j: しかし、後白河上皇が1192年に死去すると、地頭の設置範囲は次第に広がっていった。
sen.e: However, after the retired Emperor Goshirakawa died in 1192, the range of positioning was gradually spread.
However, after the retired Emperor Goshirakawa died in 1192, the range of positioning was gradually broadened.
However, after the Retired Emperor Goshirakawa died in 1192, the practice of appointing land stewards gradually spread to other territories as well.
sen.cmt: FBに基づき修正しました。

sen.j: 1221年の承久の乱での勝利により、鎌倉幕府は朝廷側の所領約3000箇所を没収した。
sen.e: As a result of the Jokyu War, Kamakura bakufu forfeited about 3000 territories from the side of Imperial Court.
As a result of the Jokyu War, Kamakura bakufu forfeited about 3000 territories from the side of the Imperial Court.
As a result of the victory in the Jokyu War in 1221, the Kamakura bakufu forfeited about 3,000 territories from the imperial court.
sen.cmt: FBに基づき修正しました。Kamakura shogunate government→Kamakura bakufuに修正

sen.j: これらの土地は西日本に所在しており、新しい地頭として多くの御家人が西日本の没収領へ移住していった。
sen.e: These territories were located in the western part of Japan, and many gokenin moved to forfeited territories in the Western Japan as new jito.
These territories were located in the western part of Japan, and many gokenin moved to the forfeited territories in Western Japan as new jito.
These territories were located in the western part of Japan, and many gokenin moved to the forfeited territories in Western Japan as new jito.

sen.j: これを新補地頭（しんぽじとう）といい、それ以前の地頭は本補地頭（ほんぽじとう）と呼ばれた。
sen.e: They are called Shinpo-Jito, and jito before that are called Honpo Jito.
They were called Shinpo-Jito, and jito before that were called Honpo Jito.
These newly appointed land stewards were called "shinpo jito" (new land stewards), while the existing ones were called "honpo jito" (hereditary land stewards).
sen.cmt: FBに基づき修正しました。

sen.j: また、新補地頭の給分を定めた規定を新補率法（しんぽりっぽう）といい、その内容は、以下の通りであった。
sen.e: Also, rules providing the Shinpo Jito's payments are called Shinpo rippo, and the contents are as follows;
Also, rules providing Shinpo Jito's payments were called Shinpo rippo, and the details were as follows;
Likewise, rules regarding the tax shares of newly appointed land stewards were called "shinpo rippo" (new taxation rules) and their details were as follows:
sen.cmt: FBに基づき修正しました。原文がピリオドで終わるよう語句を補いました。

sen.j: 田畠11町当たり1町を、年貢を荘園領主・国司へ納入する必要のない地頭給田とする。
sen.e: Rice field of 1 cho (unit of area, about 1 hectare) out of every 11 cho is made as jido kyuden, or field with no necessity to pay nengu to lords of shoen and kokushi.
A rice field of 1 cho (unit of area, about 1 hectare) out of every 11 cho was made as jido kyuden, or a field with no necessity to pay nengu to the lords of shoen and kokushi.
One cho (approximately one hectare) out of every eleven cho of farmland was given to land stewards as their property exempted from annual taxes paid to manorial lords or imperial officials.
sen.cmt: FBに基づき修正しました。

sen.j: 田畠1段当たり5升の米（加徴米）の徴収権を新補地頭へ与える。
sen.e: Right of collection of 5 sho (unit of volume) of rice is given to Shinpo Jito in every 1 dan (1/10 of cho) of rice field.
Rights of collection of 5 sho (unit of volume) of rice were given to Shinpo Jito for every 1 dan (1/10 of cho) of rice field.
The right to collect five sho (approximately 0.25 bushels) of rice per tan (approximately 10 ares) of farmland was given to newly appointed land stewards.
sen.cmt: FBに基づき修正しました。

sen.j: 山野河海の収益は、地頭と荘園領主・国司が折半する。
sen.e: Profits made in mountains, fields, rivers, and seas are split in half between jito, and lords of shoen and kokushi.
Profits made in mountains, fields, rivers, and seas were split in half between jito, and lords of shoen and kokushi.
Profits from mountains, fields, rivers and seas were split between land stewards, manorial lords and imperial officials.
sen.cmt: FBに基づき修正しました。

sen.j: 地頭の検断により逮捕された犯人の財産の3分の1が、地頭へ与えられる。
sen.e: 1/3 of the properties of a criminal who was made trial and arrested by jito is given to jito.
1/3 of the properties of a criminal who was arrested and tried by jito was given to the jito.
One-third of the property of a criminal arrested by a land steward was given to the latter.
sen.cmt: FBに基づき修正しました。

sen.j: というものだった。
sen.e: It was like that.
It was like that.
It was like that.

sen.j: ただし、土地の慣習・先例がある場合は、新補率法に優先した。
sen.e: However, if there is local custom and precedent, it had priority over Shinpo rippo.
However, if there was local custom and precedent, it had priority over Shinpo rippo.
However, local customs and precedents were given priority over these newly adopted rules.
sen.cmt: FBに基づき修正しました。

sen.j: なお、後に新補地頭を兼ねた本補地頭が、本補地頭としての給分も新補率法に合わせようとする両様兼帯の問題も生じた。
sen.e: More, there was a problem of double-positioning when a Honpo Jito who later became a Shinpo Jito concurrently tried to apply Shinpo rippo to the payments of Honpo Jito, also.
Moreover, there was a problem of double-positioning when a Honpo Jito, who later became a Shinpo Jito, concurrently tried to apply Shinpo rippo to the payments of Honpo Jito, also.
Some of the hereditary land stewards who were also appointed as new land stewards subsequently tried to apply newly adopted rules to their old tax shares, thereby causing problems.
sen.cmt: FBに基づき修正しました。

sen.j: 新補地頭として西日本へ移住した御家人には、安芸国の毛利氏・熊谷氏、豊後国の大友氏、薩摩国の千葉氏・渋谷氏などがおり、かなり大規模な移住だったため、「日本史上の民族大移動」と評する論者もいる。
sen.e: The Mori clan and Kumagaya clan of Aki Province, Otomo clan of Bungo Province, and Chiba clan and Shibuya clan of Satsuma Province are examples of gokenin who moved to the Western Japan as Shinpo Jito, and there are debaters who call it 'the great moving of people in the history of Japan,' for the size of migration was pretty big.

The Mori clan and Kumagaya clan of Aki Province, Otomo clan of Bungo Province, and Chiba clan and Shibuya clan of Satsuma Province are examples of gokenin who moved to Western Japan as Shinpo Jito, and there are those who call it 'the great movement of people in the history of Japan,' as the size of themigration was significant.

The Kamakura family's vassal clans that were appointed as new land stewards in western Japan included the Mori and Kumagaya clans of Aki Province, the Otomo clan of Bungo Province and the Chiba and Shibuya clans of Satsuma Province, and these great waves of migration are called by some the "Great Barbarian Invasion" in the history of Japan.
sen.cmt: FBに基づき修正しました。The Kamakura family's vassal clans→こちらの用語ご確認下さい。

sen.j: 鎌倉期の守護は、軍事・警察権の行使が主な任務であり、経済的権能は付与されていなかった。
sen.e: The main duty of jito in Kamakura period was exercising of military and police powers, and economical function was not granted.
The main duty of jito in the Kamakura period was exercising military and police powers, and the economical function was not granted.
The main duty of provincial military governor during the Kamakura period was to exercise military and police power, and they were not given the authority to manage economic affairs.
sen.cmt: FBに基づき修正しました。

sen.j: そのため、在地の地頭が積極的に荘園・国衙領へ侵出することができていた。
sen.e: Therefore, they could actively advance into shoen and kokuga-ryo.
Therefore, they could actively advance into shoen and kokuga-ryo.
This was the reason why local land stewards were able to expand their influence to manors and imperial territories.
sen.cmt: FBに基づき修正しました。

sen.j: しかし、室町期になると、守護に半済や使節遵行の権利が付与され、守護の経済的権能が一気に拡大することとなった。
sen.e: However, in Muromachi period, the right of hanzei (the system in the Muromachi Period where the Muromachi bakufu allowed shugo to collect half of the taxes from manors and demesnes as military fund) and shisetsu jungyo (process for implementing bakufu's decision on conflicts regarding property ownership) were given to shugo, and their economical functions were expanded at a stretch.

However, in the Muromachi period, the right of hanzei (the system in the Muromachi Period where the Muromachi bakufu allowed shugo to collect half of the taxes from manors and demesnes as military funds) and shisetsu jungyo (process for implementing bakufu's decision on conflicts regarding property ownership) were given to shugo, and their economic functions were expanded.

However, provincial military governors were accorded the right to collect half of annual taxes and to settle disputes over property during the Muromachi period, which greatly increased their economic authority.
sen.cmt: FBに基づき修正しました。

sen.j: 守護は、獲得した経済力を背景に、国内の地頭やその他の武士・名主・有力者層を被官として自らの統制下へ置こうとし、国内への影響力を強めていった。
sen.e: Shugo, with their acquired economical power as their background, strengthened their influential power inside the nation by attempting to put jito and other samurai, myoshu (owner of rice fields), and people in influential class under their control by making them hikan.

Shugo, with their acquired economic power as their background, strengthened their influential power inside the nation by attempting to put jito and other samurai, myoshu (owners of rice fields), and people in influential classes, under their control by making them hikan.

Based on newly gained economic power, provincial military governors strengthened their influence within their territories in order to subjugate land stewards, soldiers, village headmen and other influential people and to place them under their own control.
sen.cmt: FBに基づき修正しました。

sen.j: そうなると、鎌倉期以来の地頭という地位は意義を失い、従来の地頭は、他の武士・有力名主らと同様に国人（こくじん）へと変質していき、室町中期までに地頭は名実ともに消滅した。
sen.e: As a result, the importance of the position of jito since the Kamakura period had been lost, the former jito changed their nature into kokujin (local samurai) like other samurai and powerful myoshu, and by the middle Muromachi period, jito had disappeared both in name and reality.

As a result, the importance of the position of jito from the Kamakura period was lost, and the former jito changed their nature into kokujin (local samurai) like other samurai and powerful myoshu, and by the middle Muromachi period, jito had disappeared both in name and reality.

As a result, the status of land steward established during the Kamakura period declined in importance, causing land stewards to become beings similar to local samurai just like other warriors and influential village headmen and to finally disappear from history both in name and in reality by the mid-Muromachi period.
sen.cmt: FBに基づき修正しました。

tit.e: Land stewards during the Edo period
tit.cmt: FBに基づき修正しました。

sen.j: 島津氏の支配下の薩摩藩及び日向国の伊東氏支配地域では「地頭」の名称が残り、江戸時代に薩摩藩や飫肥藩となっても存続した。
sen.e: The name 'jito' remained in Satsuma Domain under the control of Shimazu clan and territories controlled by Ito clan in Hyuga province, and it existed even after it changed into Satsuma Domain and Obi Domain in Edo period.

The name 'jito' remained in the Satsuma Domain under the control of the Shimazu clan and territories controlled by the Ito clan in Hyuga province, and existed even after it changed into the Satsuma Domain and Obi Domain in the Edo period.

The title "jito" continued to be used in the Satsuma territories ruled by the Shimazu clan as well as territories in Hyuga Province ruled by the Ito clan and remained even in the Edo period, when these territories became, respectively, the Satsuma and Obi Domains.
sen.cmt: FBに基づき修正しました。Shamazu clan→Shimazu clanに修正

sen.j: 但し、前時代の「地頭」とは似て非なる物である。
sen.e: However, they are different from 'jito' in the former period.
However, they are different from 'jito' in the former period.
However, land stewards in these later periods are different in nature from those in previous periods.
sen.cmt: FBに基づき修正しました。

sen.j: 戦国時代、島津氏支配地や肝付氏支配地であった薩摩国や大隅国では「地頭」の名称が残った。
sen.e: In the Sengoku Period (Period of Warring States), the name 'jito' remained in Satsuma province and Osumi province, which were territories under control of the Shimazu clan and the Kimotsuki clan.
In the Sengoku Period (Period of Warring States), the name 'jito' remained in Satsuma province and Osumi province, which were territories under the control of the Shimazu clan and the Kimotsuki clan.
During the Sengoku period (period of Warring States), the title "jito" continued to be used in Satsuma and Osumi Provinces, which were ruled by the Shimazu and Kimotsuki clans.
sen.cmt: FBに基づき修正しました。他に合わせ、Periodの頭文字を小文字に変更

sen.j: 戦国期の地頭としては肝付氏支配地の内之浦地頭薬丸兼将や島津忠良の支配地の川辺郡 (鹿児島県)地頭奈良原長門守の名が「諸郷地頭系図」に登場する。
sen.e: The names such as Kanemasa YAKUMARU, jito of Uchinoura under the control of the Kimotsuki clan, and Narahara Nagato no kami, jito of Kawabe-gun (Kagoshima Prefecture) under the control of Tadayoshi SHIMAZU, appear in 'Shogo jito keizu' (genealogy of jito in various go, or villages).

The names such as Kanemasa YAKUMARU, jito of Uchinoura under the control of the Kimotsuki clan, and Narahara Nagato no kami, jito of Kawabe-gun (Kagoshima Prefecture) under the control of Tadayoshi SHIMAZU, appear in 'Shogo jito keizu' (genealogy of jito in various go, or villages).

Names with "jito" titles, such as Kanemasa YAKUMARU, Uchinoura Jito in the territories ruled by the Kimotsuki clan, and Narahara Nagato no kami, jito of Kawabe-gun (present-day Kagoshima Prefecture) ruled by Tadayoshi SHIMAZU, appear in 'Shogo Jito Keizu' (genealogy of land stewards in various villages).
sen.cmt: FBに基づき修正しました。原文表記に合わせ、"Shogo Jito Keizu"のクォーテーションをシングルに変更

sen.j: その後江戸時代に薩摩藩となっても存続した。
sen.e: It still existed after changing into Satsuma Domain in Edo period.
It still existed, even after changing into the Satsuma Domain in the Edo period.
The title continued to be used in these areas even in the Edo period, when they became part of the Satsuma Domain.
sen.cmt: FBに基づき修正しました。

sen.j: 当初、地頭は現地に移住していた。
sen.e: At first, jito moved to the location of duty.
At first, jito moved to the location of their duty.
Initially, land stewards moved to live in local communities that they were assigned to.
sen.cmt: FBに基づき修正しました。

sen.j: この勤務形態を「居地頭」という。
sen.e: This form of working is called 'Kyo-jito'（居地頭）.
This form of working was called 'Kyo-jito'（居地頭）.
This type of steward system is known as "full-time (or live-in) steward" system ("kyo jito" in Japanese).
sen.cmt: FBに基づき修正しました。

sen.j: 寛永年間以降は藩の重役が兼務する事が多くなり、任期中も鹿児島城下に居住した。
sen.e: After Kanei era, it became common to be double-assigned to the directors of domain, and they lived in Kagoshima Castle town even in their term of duty.
After the Kanei era, it became common to be double-assigned as directors of domain, and they lived in Kagoshima Castle town even during their term of duty.

From the Kanei era (early 17th century) onward, it became common for executives of the Satsuma Domain to be concurrently appointed as land stewards, and these executives continued to live in areas around Kagoshima-jo Castle even during their tenure of office as land stewards.
sen.cmt: FBに基づき修正しました。他の表記に合わせ、domainの頭文字を大文字に変更、Kagoshima-jo Castleとしました。

sen.j: これを「掛持ち地頭」という。
sen.e: They were called 'Kakemochi-jito.'
They were called 'Kakemochi-jito.'
These land stewards were called "part-time stewards" ("kakemochi jito" in Japanese).
sen.cmt: FBに基づき修正しました。

sen.j: 明治初期にも本職は残った。
sen.e: This position was also remained in the early Meiji period, and an example like when the Hongo clan, who were feudal lord of Miyakonojo City of Hyuga province for a long time, was moved into Kagoshima City, Michitsune MISHIMA was sent as a jito, showed shrewdness in soothing discontented warrior class, and continued his duty until Haihan-chiken (abolition of feudal domains and establishment of prefectures) can be seen.

This position also remained in the early Meiji period, and an example such as the Hongo clan, who were feudal lords of Miyakonojo City of Hyuga province for a long time, was moved to Kagoshima City, and Michitsune MISHIMA was sent as a jito, and showed shrewdness in soothing the discontented warrior class, and continued his duties until Haihan-chiken (abolition of feudal domains and the establishment of prefectures) can be seen.
The title continued to be used even in the early Meiji period.
sen.cmt: FBに基づき修正しました。一原文一訳文の例外対処

sen.j: 長年にわたって日向国都城市領主であった北郷氏が、鹿児島市内に移された後、地頭として三島通庸が送られ、不平士族をなだめるのに辣腕を発揮し、廃藩置県までその職を務めた例がみられる。
sen.e: For example, after the Hongo clan that had ruled Miyakonojo City of Hyuga Province for a long period of time was transferred to Kagoshima City, Michitsune MISHIMA was sent out to Miyakonojo City as the land steward and efficiently managed to appease the discontented samurai, fulfilling his duty until the abolition of feudal domains and the establishment of prefectures.
sen.cmt: FBに基づき修正しました。一原文一訳文の例外対処

sen.j: また、明治期の伊集院郷の地頭には郷士が採用された。
sen.e: Also, goshi (country samurai) was hired as jito in Ijuin-go (Ijuin village) of Meiji period.
Also, goshi (country samurai) were hired as jito in Ijuin-go (Ijuin village) in the Meiji period.
It is also known that an indigenous samurai (called "goshi" in Japanese) was hired as the land steward of Ijuin Village during the Meiji period.
sen.cmt: FBに基づき修正しました。

sen.j: 役職内容は江戸幕府の関東付近の代官とほぼ同じである。
sen.e: The contents of duty were almost same as the local governor of Edo bakufu in around Kanto region.
The details of the duties were almost same as the local governor of Edo bakufu in and around the Kanto region.
The duties of land stewards during the Edo period were almost the same as those of local governors in the Kanto region appointed by the Edo bakufu.
sen.cmt: FBに基づき修正しました。Edo shogunate→Edo bakufuに修正

sen.j: 薩摩藩では薩摩藩家臣の領地である私領と藩主直轄地に分かれるが、地頭は直轄地の方に配属された。
sen.e: In Satsuma Domain, there are private land for the territories of vassals of domain and land under direct control of the lord of the domain, and jito was appointed to the land controlled by the lord.

In the Satsuma Domain, there was private land for the territories of vassals of domain and land under the direct control of the lord of the domain, and jito were appointed to the land controlled by the lord.

In the Satsuma Domain, land was divided into two categories - i.e. private land owned by the retainers of the domain and land directly managed by the lord of the domain - and land stewards were allocated to the latter category of land.
sen.cmt: FBに基づき修正しました。

sen.j: 江戸幕府の代官との一番の違いは、薩摩藩の大半の郷の地頭は家老や側用人、勘定奉行や町奉行等の薩摩藩重役が兼務していた点である。
sen.e: The biggest difference between the local governor of Edo bakufu is that the most of the jito post of go (villages) in Satsuma Domain were concurrently held by the directors of Satsuma Domain, such as chief retainer, sobayonin (lord chamberlain), kanjo bugyo （commissioner of finance), machi-bugyo (town magistrate), and so on.

The biggest difference between the local governor of Edo bakufu was that most of the jito posts of go (villages) in the Satsuma Domain were concurrently held by the directors of the Satsuma Domain, such as chief retainer, sobayonin (lord chamberlain), kanjo bugyo （commissioner of finance), machi-bugyo (town magistrate), and so on.

The biggest difference with local governors appointed by the Edo bakufu was that most of the village land stewards in the Satsuma Domain were executives of the domain, including chief retainers, lord chamberlains, commissioners of finance and town magistrates, who were concurrently appointed as jito.
sen.cmt: FBに基づき修正しました。Edo shogunate→Edo bakufuに修正

sen.j: また、上は一所持から下は一代小番（御小姓与や新番が10人扶持級以上の役職についてなったもの）までの城下士が就任した。
sen.e: Also, samurai in the castle, from the top issho mochi (literally, one-place holders) to the bottom ichidai koban (a name given to samurai of Okoshogumi family rank and shinban, or new guard, who became to hold a position with salary of more than 10 people) were assumed.

Also, samurai in the castle, from the top issho mochi (literally, one-place holders) to the bottom ichidai koban (a name given to samurai of Okoshogumi family rank and shinban, or new guards, who came to hold a position with a salary of more than 10 people) were assumed.

Also, land stewards were chosen from among retainers living in areas around the castle, including high ranking retainers who had large private estates (called "isshomochi") as well as low ranking retainers called "ichidai koban" (non-hereditary lackeys and servants who were appointed as officials with incomes to support 10 persons or more).
sen.cmt: FBに基づき修正しました。

sen.j: 郷での実際の行政は上級郷士により運営されていた。
sen.e: The actual administration of go were ran by upper-class goshi.
The actual administration of go was performed by upper-class goshi.
The actual administration of village affairs was delegated to the upper-class indigenous samurai.
sen.cmt: FBに基づき修正しました。

sen.j: また、一部の郷では地頭代が派遣された。
sen.e: Also, jito-dai (deputy jito) were dispatched to some of go.
Also, jito-dai (deputy jito) were dispatched to some go.
Deputy land stewards were sent out to some of the villages.
sen.cmt: FBに基づき修正しました。

sen.j: なお「掛持ち地頭」の勤務形態になって以降、基本的には地頭は城下に滞在し行政は地元の郷士に任せていたが、藩法上、地頭は就任から4年～5年以内に1回目の現地視察を義務づけられていた。
sen.e: Further, after becoming the duty form of 'Kakemochi-jito,' jito basically stayed in the castle and left administration in local goshi's hands, but the law of domain obligated jito to inspect their territory once in every 4 - 5 years.

Further, after assuming the duty form of 'Kakemochi-jito,' jito basically stayed in the castle and left administration in the local goshi's hands, but the law of the domain obligated jito to inspect their territory once every 4 - 5 years.

After the part-time land steward system was introduced, land stewards normally stayed in areas around the castle, delegating administrative authority to indigenous samurai living in local communities, but they were obligated to inspect their territories within four to five years after their appointment as land stewards.
sen.cmt: FBに基づき修正しました。

sen.j: また藩重役には私領主も就任していたので、例えば吉利（現在の日置市日吉町吉利）領主小松清猷が清水郷（現在の霧島市国分清水町他）地頭職に就任したように、私領主が地頭を兼任することもあった。
sen.e: Also, lords of private land were also assumed as a director of domain, so like Kiyomoto KOMATSU, lord of Yoshitoshi (present day Yoshitoshi, Hiyoshi-cho, Hioki City), who was positioned as jitoshiki of Kiyomizu-go (around present day Kokubunkiyomizu-cho, Kirishima City), sometimes lords of private land were concurrently assumed as jito.

Also, lords of private land were also assumed as director of domain, so like Kiyomoto KOMATSU, lord of Yoshitoshi (present day Yoshitoshi, Hiyoshi-cho, Hioki City), who was positioned as jitoshiki of Kiyomizu-go (around present day Kokubunkiyomizu-cho, Kirishima City), sometimes lords of private land were concurrently assumed as jito.

Executives of the domain included owners of private estates, who were also concurrently appointed as the land stewards of their estates, as shown by the example of Kiyomoto KOMATSU, the owner of the estate of Yoshitoshi (present-day Yoshitoshi, Hiyoshi-cho, Hioki City), who was appointed as the land steward of Kiyomizu-go (present-day Kokubunkiyomizu-cho and other areas in Kirishima City).
sen.cmt: FBに基づき修正しました。

sen.j: ただし、居地頭制が存続した長島 (鹿児島県)や甑島の地頭は他職との兼職ではなく「無役之移地頭」と呼ばれ、席次は船奉行と物頭の間に置かれた。
sen.e: However, in Nagashima (Kagoshima Prefecture) and Koshikijima where the system of Kyo-jito remained, jito were not concurrently assumed with other duties and were called 'Muyaku no I-jito' (無役之移地頭), and the rank was positioned between fune bugyo (magistrate of ships) and monogashira (military commanders).
sen.cmt: 無役之移地頭→読み不明です
sen.e: However, in Nagashima (Kagoshima Prefecture) and Koshikijima where the system of Kyo-jito remained, jito were not concurrently assumed with other duties and were called 'Muyaku no I-jito' (無役之移地頭), and the rank was positioned between fune bugyo (magistrate of ships) and monogashira (military commanders).

However, on Nagashima (Kagoshima Prefecture) and Koshiki-jima islands where the old land steward system remained, land stewardship was a full-time position known as a "job without other duties," and it was ranked between ship marshal and military commander.
sen.cmt: FBに基づき修正しました。

sen.j: 「三州御治世要覧」によると、小姓与格や新番格の武士が地頭に就任すると、家格を「代々小番」に昇格させることができる特権があった。
sen.e: According to 'Sanshu gochisei yoran,' when samurai of rank of koshogumi and shinban were assumed as jito, they gained the special privilege of having their family rank promoted to 'daidai koban (successive title of koban army).'
sen.cmt: 三州御治世要覧→定訳不明です
sen.e: According to 'Sanshu gochisei yoran,' when samurai of the rank koshogumi and shinban were assumed as jito, they gained the special privilege of having their family rank promoted to 'daidai koban (successive title of koban army).'

According to 'Sanshu Gochisei Yoran' (Summary History of Satsuma, Osumi and Hyuga Provinces), low ranking samurai who served as lackeys and servants were given the privilege of being promoted to the rank of hereditary guard if they were appointed as land stewards.
sen.cmt: FBに基づき修正しました。原文表記に基づき、 "Sanshu Gochisei Yoran"のクォーテーションをシングルに変更

sen.j: 通常、小姓与格や新番格の武士が10人扶持以上の役職に就任すると「一代小番」に昇格することが出来たがこれは本人一代限りの昇格であり、子孫は元来の家格のままであった。
sen.e: Normally, samurai of rank of koshogumi and shinban were able to bo promoted as 'ichidai koban' when they were assumed to post with salary of more than 10 people, but this was a promotion that only lasts in their generation, and the rank of their descendants would be remained as the former ones.

Normally, samurai of the rank koshogumi and shinban were able to be promoted as 'ichidai koban' when they assumed a post with a salary of more than 10 people, but this was a promotion that only lasted for their generation, and the rank of their descendants returned to the former one.

Samurai retainers who assumed a position with an income to support 10 persons or more were promoted to the rank of guard, which, however, was non-hereditary rank, so that their descendants remained in the previous family rank.
sen.cmt: FBに基づき修正しました。

sen.j: 更に、世襲の代々小番に昇格するには側役以上の役職に就くか、三代続けて10人扶持以上の職に就く必要があった。
sen.e: Moreover, in order to be promoted as daidai koban, which was inherited, it was necessary to be assumed to the post higher than sobayaku (secretary), or to be assumed to the post with salary of more than 10 people for three consecutive generations.

Moreover, in order to be promoted as daidai koban, which was inherited, it was necessary to assume a post higher than sobayaku (secretary), or to assumea post with a salary of more than 10 people for three consecutive generations.

In order to be promoted to the rank of hereditary guard, it was necessary to hold a post higher than secretary or assume a position with an income to support 10 persons or more for three successive generations.
sen.cmt: FBに基づき修正しました。

sen.j: しかし、地頭を兼務すると一代で代々小番に昇格できた。
sen.e: However, when assumed concurrently to jito, they could be promoted to daidai koban in one generation.
However, when assumed concurrently to jito, they could be promoted to daidai koban in one generation.
However, being concurrently appointed as a land steward gave the privilege of being promoted to the rank of hereditary guard in a single generation.
sen.cmt: FBに基づき修正しました。

sen.j: また、後任の地頭が決まらない地は「明所」と呼ばれ、大番頭職の管理下に置かれた。
sen.e: Also, a territory with no successive jito was called 'meisho' (明所), and it was put under the control of oban gashira (captains of the great guards).
Also, a territory with no successive jito was called 'meisho' (明所), and it was put under the control of oban gashira (captains of the great guards).
Also, a territory with no successive jito was called 'meisho' (明所), and it was put under the control of oban gashira (captains of the great guards).

sen.j: 但し、出水郡や志布志町、伊集院町といった重要な郷に関しては明所とせずに他の郷の地頭が兼任した。
sen.e: However, in important go such as Izumi-gun, Shibushi town, and Ijuin town, it was not made into meisho, but was ruled concurrently by jito of other go.
However, in important go such as Izumi-gun, Shibushi town, and Ijuin town, it was not made into meisho, but was ruled concurrently by jito of other go.

However, if there was no person appointed to succeed the current land steward of an important local territory, such as Izumi-gun, Shibushi town and Ijuin town, a land steward of other territory was appointed to govern the territory in order to avoid making it a vacant territory.
sen.cmt: FBに基づき修正しました。

sen.j: 例えば島津久風は加世田郷地頭時代に二度出水郷地頭を兼務している。
sen.e: For example, Hisakaze SHIMAZU was assumed concurrently twice as the jito of Izumi go when he was the jito of Kaseda go.
For example, Hisakaze SHIMAZU was assumed concurrently twice as the jito of Izumi go when he was the jito of Kaseda go.
For example, Hisakaze SHIMAZU was concurrently appointed as the land steward of Izumi Village twice while he was serving also as the land steward of Kaseda Village.
sen.cmt: FBに基づき修正しました。Hisakaze SHIMAXU→Hisakaze SHIMAZUに修正

sen.j: なお、この場合、島津久風は『加世田郷地頭兼出水郷地頭』ではなく、『加世田郷地頭及び出水郷預かり（『差引』と表記される場合も）』となる。
sen.e: Further, in this case, Hisakaze SHIMAZU would not be called "Jito of Kaseda go and Izumi go", but be called "Jito of Kaseda go and Izumi go azukari (in custody of Izumi go) (sometimes written as "sashihiki," too)."

Further, in this case, Hisakaze SHIMAZU would not be called "Jito of Kaseda go and Izumi go", but was called "Jito of Kaseda go and Izumi go azukari (in custody of Izumi go) (sometimes written as "sashihiki," too)."

In this case, Hisakaze SHIMAZU's official title was not "land steward of Kaseda and Izumi Villages" but "land steward of Kaseda Village, who was also in charge of Izumi Village" (sometimes also called "sashihiki" (person in charge)).
sen.cmt: FBに基づき修正しました。

sen.j: 飫肥藩においても、地頭職の名称が残った。
sen.e: The name jitoshiki also remained in Obi Domain, too.
The name jitoshiki also remained in Obi Domain, too.
The tile "jitoshiki" continued to be used in the Obi Domain as well.
sen.cmt: FBに基づき修正しました。

sen.j: とくに重要な地頭職は清武町地頭であり、飫肥藩東北の要である清武における藩主代理ともいえる職であった。
sen.e: Especially important jitoshiki was the jito of Kiyotake town, and it was a position that could be considered as the deputy of the lord of domain in Kiyotake, the pivotal territory in north-eastern part of Obi Domain.

An especially important jitoshiki was the jito of Kiyotake town, and it was a position that could be considered as the deputy of the lord of the domain in Kiyotake, the pivotal territory in the north-eastern part of the Obi Domain.
The land steward of Kiyotake town, who represented the lord of the domain in Kiyotake, a pivotal territory in the north-eastern part of the Obi Domain, was of particularly importance.
sen.cmt: FBに基づき修正しました。

sen.j: 天保13年（1842年）の飫肥藩分限帳では、清武地頭の他に、酒谷地頭や北河内地頭、油津港地頭、大堂津地頭などが散見できる。
sen.e: In Obi Domain Bugencho (registers of vassals) in 1842, names of jito of Sakatani, Kitagawachi, Aburatsu-ko Port, and Odotsu could be found here and there other than jito of Kiyotake.
In Obi Domain Bugencho (registers of vassals) in 1842, the names of jito of Sakatani, Kitagawachi, Aburatsu-ko Port, and Odotsu could be found other than jito of Kiyotake.

In addition Kiyotake jito (Kiyotake land steward), titles such as Sakatani jito, Kitagawachi jito, Aburatsu-ko Port jito and Odotsu jito are found in the Obi Domain's register of vassals recorded in 1842.
sen.cmt: FBに基づき修正しました。

sen.j: なお、地頭は薩摩藩同様に城下士より任命された。
sen.e: Further, jito, like Satsuma Domain, were assumed from samurai in the castle, and jito of Kiyotake was chosen from umamawari (horse guards), but other jito were also chosen from nakakosho (groom and/or stableman), who were ranked as chushi, and kachi (foot guards), who were ranked as kashi.

Further, jito, like Satsuma Domain, were assumed from samurai in the castle, and jito of Kiyotake were chosen from umamawari (horse guards), but other jito were also chosen from nakakosho (groom and/or stableman), who were ranked as chushi, and kachi (foot guards), who were ranked as kashi.
In the Obi Domain, land stewards were chosen from among samurai retainers living in areas around the castle as in the Satsuma Domain.
sen.cmt: FBに基づき修正しました。一原文一訳文の例外対処

sen.j: 清武地頭は馬廻から出たが、その他の地頭は中士である中小姓や下士である徒士からも出た。
sen.e: However, the land steward of Kiyotake was chosen from among horse guards (called "umamawari" in Japanese), while land stewards of other territories were chosen from among middle ranking retainers who served as servants or low ranking foot soldiers.
sen.cmt: FBに基づき修正しました。一原文一訳文の例外対処

sen.j: 当初、清武地頭は宝永2年（1705年）から正徳 (日本)3年（1713年）まで伊東織部祐全が就任した以外はほとんど河崎氏が就任していたが、享保9年（1724年）5月に長倉善左衛門が就任して以後は河崎氏以外が就任した。
sen.e: At first, from1705 through 1713, jito of Kiyotake was mostly assumed by the Kawasaki clan except for when ITO Oribe Yuzen (伊東織部祐全) was assigned, but after Zenzaemon NAGAKURA assumed the position in May of 1724, samurai other than the Kawasaki clan were assumed.
sen.cmt: 伊東織部祐全→読み不明です
sen.e: At first, from 1705 through 1713, jito of Kiyotake was mostly assumed by the Kawasaki clan, except when ITO Oribe Yuzen (伊東織部祐全) was assigned, but after Zenzaemon NAGAKURA assumed the position in May of 1724, samurai other than the Kawasaki clan were assumed.

Initially, the land steward of Kiyotake was almost always chosen from the members of the Kawasaki clan, except for ITO Oribe Yuzen, who served as the steward from 1705 until 1713, but after Zenzaemon NAGAKURA assumed the position in June 1724, retainers other than members of the Kawasaki clan were appointed for the position.
sen.cmt: FBに基づき修正しました。統一事項より、旧暦→グレゴリオ暦に修正
